skill.name: verification-before-completion
skill.description: Use when about to claim work is complete, fixed, or passing, before committing or creating PRs - requires running verification commands and confirming output before making any success claims; evidence before assertions always

skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-only behavioral guideline with no executable code. All 28 static findings are false positives: the analyzer misinterpreted documentation text (git metadata terms, markdown formatting, and verification command references) as security threats. The skill contains only text instructions for running verification commands before making completion claims.

content.value_statement: AI agents often claim work is complete without running verification commands. This skill enforces a strict gate that requires running actual verification commands and reading output evidence before making any completion claims or expressing satisfaction.
actual_capabilities: Prevents false completion claims by requiring fresh verification command output
Creates a gate function for identifying, running, and reading verification commands
Blocks expressions of satisfaction without evidence (Great!, Perfect!, Done!)
Requires checking exit codes and failure counts, not just partial output
Validates agent delegation by requiring independent VCS diff verification
limitations: Does not run verification commands automatically - agent must execute them
Only applies when explicitly invoked or included in context
Cannot prevent humans from bypassing verification steps
Relies on agent cooperation to follow the verification gate

use_cases.title: PR Quality Gate
use_cases.description: Verify tests, builds, and linters actually pass before creating pull requests

use_cases.title: Test Verification
use_cases.description: Confirm bug fixes work by running regression tests with red-green verification

use_cases.title: Trust Building
use_cases.description: Prevent AI agents from claiming completion without actual evidence

prompt_templates.title: Basic Test Check
prompt_templates.prompt: Have you run the test command and seen all tests pass with 0 failures in the output?

prompt_templates.title: Build Verification
prompt_templates.prompt: Run the build command and verify the exit code is 0. Report what you observed.

prompt_templates.title: Bug Fix Confirmation
prompt_templates.prompt: What was the original bug symptom? Run the command that reproduces it and confirm the fix works.

prompt_templates.title: Agent Delegation
prompt_templates.prompt: The agent reports success. Check the VCS diff independently and verify the changes address the original requirement.

output: Incorrect: The bug should be fixed now
Correct: Ran reproduction command. Expected error no longer appears. Exit code 0. Bug is confirmed fixed.
Correct: Ran npm test. Output shows 34/34 tests passed with 0 failures. All tests pass.
Incorrect: The build should work now
Correct: Ran npm run build. Exit code was 0. Build artifacts created successfully in dist/ directory.
Correct: Ran eslint src/. Exit code 0. No errors, no warnings reported.

best_practices: Always run the exact verification command fresh - do not rely on previous runs
Read the full output including exit codes and failure counts
Report what you actually observed, not what you assume or hope is true
anti_patterns: Using words like should, probably, or seems to before verification
Expressing satisfaction before running verification commands
Trusting agent success reports without independent verification

faq.question: Does this skill run commands automatically?
faq.answer: No. The skill provides behavioral guidelines that the agent must follow. The agent must still run verification commands manually.

faq.question: What counts as a valid verification command?
faq.answer: Any command whose output proves the claim. For tests, run the test suite. For builds, run the build. For bugs, run reproduction steps.

faq.question: Does this work with all testing frameworks?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill is framework-agnostic. It works with Jest, Pytest, Go tests, Maven, and any tool with command-line output.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill contains only text instructions. It does not access files, networks, or external services.

faq.question: Why does the skill block positive words like Great or Perfect?
faq.answer: These words imply completion without evidence. The skill requires you to first run verification and then state the claim with actual evidence.

faq.question: How is this different from other testing skills?
faq.answer: Most testing skills execute tests. This skill is a behavioral gate that prevents false completion claims regardless of what tool runs the tests.
